bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, December 29, 1937

div1.p: Moran supplies Hench with addresses of Andrus and Hanberry - both yellow fever experiment volunteers. He suggests that the Mayo Clinic assist Andrus with his health problems.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, December 29, 1937
div1.opener:
COMPAÑIA SUNOCO DE CUBA, S.A.
AGENTES EXCLUSIVOS DE
SUN OIL COMPANY
SUN OILS
AVENIDA MENOCAL NO. 102-A
HABANA,
Dec. 29, 1937.
CABLE Y}
TELEGRAFO}
“SUNOCO”
CLAVE BENTLEY
TELEFONO U-6148
SUNOCO
DESTILADO AL MERCURIO
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
MAYO CLINIC,
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Following up my letter dated December 18th and in
further reply to footnote in your letter dated September 22nd, I beg to
give you the names and addresses of the two survivors referred to in my
last letter, as follows:
Mr. J. H. Andrus,
805 Cooper Street,
CAMDEN, N. J.
Mr. James L. Hanberry,
61 Summers Avenue,
Orangeburg, S. C.

I gather from a recent letter from Mr. Andrus that he
has been corresponding with the those of the eighteen experimented upon and
still in the land of the living. A few days ago I wrote to him requesting
for the list, with addresses, informing him that it was for your good self.

I quote from Mr. Andrus' letter, as follows:
“One of the reasons I wanted to get in touch with all my
fellow guinea pigs was to ascertain if any others have had spinal
trouble similar to mine. Was at Walter Reed Hospital from May
13, until October 6, 1932 and the medicos there diagnosed my
trouble as syringomyelia. My son, a graduate of Hahnemann
Medical College, does not agree. He says “spinal arthritis”.
I have been bedfast since Mrach, 1932, and am told that I can
never walk again”

I have quoted the above to you for a reason. I have
been thinking that MAYO CLINIC might take an interest in this man's case,
thru your kind intervention. I have not even suggested such action to
Mr. Andrus, but I feel reasonably sure you would be interested in his
sorry plight. I trust you will pardon me for “wishing” trouble on to
you. I do not know Mr. Andrus' economic situation. I am sure, however,
that his son (a medico) will assist him in every possible manner.
